            $(this).keypress(function (e) {

<h1 class="literature-h1">
<span class="literature-header"><span class="subheader-h2" id="top">
        A Tale of Two Cities</span> <span class="subheader-author" id="innerlayout_0_ctl10_spAuthor">
            By
            Charles Dickens</span> </span><span class="subheader-h3">
</span> <span class="subheader-h3">
<i>A Tale of Two Cities </i>at a Glance</span>
</h1>
<div class="page-navigation summary">
<div class="next-page right" id="innerlayout_0_phtoppager_0_divNextPage">
<a href="/literature/t/a-tale-of-two-cities/book-summary" title="Book Summary"><span>Next</span>
<br>
<span class="next-page-title">Book Summary</span>
</br></a>
</div>
<div class="clear">
</div>
</div>
<div class="article-content">
<div id="litnote-content">
<div id="innerlayout_0_contentbody_0_separator" style="float:left; margin:0 10px 10px 0;">
<img src="/CliffsNotes/includes/images/content-ad-bgrd.gif"/>
<div class="placement" id="SquareAdSpace">
<script type="text/javascript">
            googletag.cmd.push(function ()
            {
                googletag.display("SquareAdSpace");
            });
        </script>
</div>
</div>
<p class="litNoteText"><em>A Tale of Two Cities</em>, by Charles Dickens, deals with the major themes of duality, revolution, and resurrection. It was the best of times, it was the worst of times in London and Paris, as economic and political unrest lead to the American and French Revolutions. The main characters in Dickens' <em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> — <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=EBE892E5C8074F89BAB064F34B464821&amp;_z=z">Doctor Alexandre Manette</a>, <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=A99FB18713CA4B74B5F0CE9A4B6B5A88&amp;_z=z">Charles Darnay</a>, and <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=A1EE5C4CC1954AF2860E04624A36AE4A&amp;_z=z">Sydney Carton</a> — are all recalled to life, or resurrected, in different ways as turmoil erupts.</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Written by:</strong> <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=A99FB18713CA4B74B5F0CE9A4B6B5A88&amp;_z=z">Charles Dickens</a></p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Type of Work:</strong> novel</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Genres: </strong>historical fiction; political commentary</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>First Published:</strong> In weekly installments in <em>All the Year Round</em>, from April 30 to November 29, 1859</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Setting:</strong> London and Paris, 1775-1792</p>
<p class="litNoteText"> <strong><a href="~/link.aspx?_id=D608008C8E2E4C1FA233C30E1A9B5970&amp;_z=z">Main Characters</a>:</strong> <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=EBE892E5C8074F89BAB064F34B464821&amp;_z=z">Doctor Alexandre Manette</a>; <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=6694413AC043478D99A3C409932C68FC&amp;_z=z">Lucie Manette (later Darnay)</a>; <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=A99FB18713CA4B74B5F0CE9A4B6B5A88&amp;_z=z">Charles Darnay</a>; <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=A1EE5C4CC1954AF2860E04624A36AE4A&amp;_z=z">Sydney Carton</a>; <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=0309749CBE7645269CF77C615983B867&amp;_z=z">Therese Defarge</a>; <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=0A1593104EAF4AEDA41E1E6F128641F1&amp;_z=z">Ernest Defarge</a>; <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=2739DDA7FC114A0DAF821E25D378C2C9&amp;_z=z">Jerry Cruncher</a>; Mr. Lorry; Miss Pross</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Major Thematic Topics:</strong> duality; revolution; resurrection; violence; centrality of women; aristocratic versus peasant</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Motifs:</strong> darkness; restricted by society; duality</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Major Symbols: </strong>Madame Defarge's Knitting; motherhood</p>
<p class="litNoteText"><strong>Movie Versions: </strong><a href="~/link.aspx?_id=CDFAB415FC9D4A4187B5C3B3B3DD2047&amp;_z=z"><em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> (1935)</a>; <em></em><a href="~/link.aspx?_id=CDFAB415FC9D4A4187B5C3B3B3DD2047&amp;_z=z"><em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> (1958)</a>; <em></em><a href="~/link.aspx?_id=CDFAB415FC9D4A4187B5C3B3B3DD2047&amp;_z=z"><em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> (1980)</a>; <em></em><a href="~/link.aspx?_id=CDFAB415FC9D4A4187B5C3B3B3DD2047&amp;_z=z"><em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> (1989)</a></p>
<p class="litNoteText">The three most important aspects of <em>A Tale of Two Cities:</em></p>
<ul>
<li><em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> is told from the <em>omniscient</em>, or all-knowing, point of view. The narrator, or storyteller, who is never identified, has access to the thoughts and feelings of all the characters.</li>
<p>
</p>
<li><em>A Tale of Two </em>Cities, which is one of two historical novels written by Charles Dickens, is set in London and in Paris and the French countryside at the time of the <a href="~/link.aspx?_id=CA9EE02CD5784444939BF31AF668A47C&amp;_z=z">French Revolution</a>. The book is sympathetic to the overthrow of the French aristocracy but highly critical of the reign of terror that followed.</li>
<li>Dickens characterizes the men and women who populate <em>A Tale of Two Cities</em> less by what the book's narrator or the characters themselves say, and more by what they do. As a result, the novel seems somewhat modern, despite being set in the 18th century and written in the 19th century.</li>
</ul>
</div>
